Experiment comments:
Scientific and tech. support was excellent, the staff is qualified, friendly, supportive and timely. Thank you for the great measurement time!

Two extra-long injections and a beam loss interrupted our measurements. I remember these problems plagued synchrotrons in the last century, but these days they are rather unusual. Hence my reduced rating for the ring this time.

The software does the job, but is overly complicated, on one hand, and too rigid, on the other. It does not allow the visitors to specify a *single* data collection directory for a visit, trying to create per-project and per-date directories instead (and crashing the process...). The single per-visit root would make backups and data checks much easier. All other attributes (metadata such as project, user, etc.) should be recorded in a database and/or in XML/JSON/key-value pair text files.

The dataset should be identified by a *single* identifier, supplied by the *user* (*not* by the beamline software), and used to name dataset directory and images within. Now we have to duplicate the ID, which is tedious, distracting and error prone.

The beamline processing software clutters our processing directories with undocumented and sometimes redundant large files -- this wastes disk space, backup time and puts extra burden on data management. It also launches processes on our data that are nowhere specified and interfere with our data processing. It would be better if we as users would have full control on what software is started on our collected data and when, and what files are recorded (there is no need to store a file and its gzipped version, or TMP files in the PROCESSED_DATA tree). Thus, the software could be improved along these lines, IMHO.
Infrastructure comment: Great users service, thank you! And thanks for the sponsored coffee, it helps to stay awake during the night shifts :)
Overall comments: Despite some glitches, the measurement was a fun and overly successful. Would like to visit MaxLAB once more :)
Remarks: How can the users get more closely involved in the beam line software development?

Experiment comments:
We have needed a lot of support from Christopher Söderberg, partly because we have 'pushed' the beamline very hard (very demanding experiments, and unusual type of data collection) - and we have been very happy with the support we have received. At all the occasions where we have called, Christopher has either solved the problem over the phone or he has come in and fixed the needs. Thank you very much.
The beamline quality has improved very much since our last data collection in October 2013. We have also been here for teh BIOSAS course feb 2014, and again we experience improvements since Feb. Clearly, the strategy for upgrading the user-friendliness of the beamline is working. We have collected more than 2x the amount of data compared to previous visits, AND in general the reproducibility of the data is much higher than before. 
We have experienced the following kind of bugs and problems:
Robot stuck: Happens when the water/air arm does not return after use. Solved by resetting software and hardware. Happened maybe 10 times.

Lost connection between software and hardware for robot: Discovered one bug, if placing a comment in the comment line (with robot load) the program loses connection after first exposure (cannot open shutter again).
If changing the robot-speed also some times the connection was lost. 
We lost connection to SPEC. Solved by restarting everything (aided by Christopher over the phone).

Over Sunday night, the general stability of the incoming beam was lowered. It appeared to be local (instrument), not the ring. We did not discover the source of the problem. We do notice that the robot, when going at full speed, can cause some of the problems.
During the rest of the experiment it was much better, and in general the stability was significnatly higher than at earlier visits, very much appreciated (since we need to compare data over many hours).
Pipeline crashed a couple of times, but when it works it is very convenient. It ensures that the user can follow the data collection and hence optimize the data colelction prior to departure, so it is very much appreciated that the pipeline is installed.
Suggestions, please see below.

Please note, again, that the overall quality of the beamline has improved significantly!
BTW we also appreciate the efficient air-driven temperature control on the sample plates.

Two extra-long injections and a beam loss interrupted our measurements. I remember these problems plagued synchrotrons in the last century, but these days they are rather unusual. Hence my reduced rating for the ring this time.

The software does the job, but is overly complicated, on one hand, and too rigid, on the other. It does not allow the visitors to specify a *single* data collection directory for a visit, trying to create per-project and per-date directories instead (and crashing the process...). The single per-visit root would make backups and data checks much easier. All other attributes (metadata such as project, user, etc.) should be recorded in a database and/or in XML/JSON/key-value pair text files.

The dataset should be identified by a *single* identifier, supplied by the *user* (*not* by the beamline software), and used to name dataset directory and images within. Now we have to duplicate the ID, which is tedious, distracting and error prone.

The beamline processing software clutters our processing directories with undocumented and sometimes redundant large files -- this wastes disk space, backup time and puts extra burden on data management. It also launches processes on our data that are nowhere specified and interfere with our data processing. It would be better if we as users would have full control on what software is started on our collected data and when, and what files are recorded (there is no need to store a file and its gzipped version, or TMP files, in the PROCESSED_DATA tree). Thus, the software could be improved along these lines, IMHO.

In general, the beamline was in excellent condition. The recent enhancements to the end-station (manipulator motorization and analysis chamber camera) are excellent, although one might want to consider installing safety stoppers to the lid and gate valve between prep and analysis chamber. Now it's too easy to crash the manipulator since one is often sitting in the hutch during long z movements. A safety stopper switch in the gate valve (and lid) would stop the z movement before the manipulator rod hits it. 

Manipulator control software had minor bugs and the SES computer was somewhat sluggish, but these were minor inconveniences. 

The sample transfer and storage system is impressive in its simplicity and reliability. In total we measured 26 samples and there were absolutely no problems transferring samples in and out. In the future one might consider having a larger turbo in the loadlock chamber as it would cut down the pumping time for new samples, but it's not critical. 

There was a bad beam on Saturday morning/day. It would be nice if the Machine operators could post more detailed comments on the Message Board regarding beam problems. In particular, it would be good to know if a poor beam is just a one-off incident or if it will persist in the future.

Now we had to borrow a large N2 cylinder and move it in and out of the lab.

Overall comments:
The problems noted in the earlier week associated with proposal 20120262 were uncorrected in that the GRACE spectrometer could not obtain F K edge XES emission spectra due to the blocking of the line of sight of the principal ray within the GRACE spectrometer. The program of measurements was much altered to essentially focus only on x-ray absorption. An attempt at high resolution O K-edge XES from other samples was made, but as the emission calibration test using a Na Kalpha line in second order indicated a very oddly distributed vertical focussing of the beam giving rise to three distinct emission sources, it was clear that high resolution XES was impossible without other measures. To compensate for slitless operation, a slit was mounted on one of the samples, but alignment and countrate issues prevented any useful measurements. 

Finally, the XAS measurements themselves were hampered as the sample stick was not electrically isolated to allow for sample drain TEY measurements. The alternative sample stick which allowed for sample drain TEY had such a limited range of x-y movement, that it proved impossible to do grazing incidence measurements onto these sample surfaces. The resultant XAS measurements using the first sample stick required separate scans for TEY and TFY, both obtained by the channeltron detector in differing polarities. Unfortunately for the samples that optically fluoresced the TEY was compromised by the contribution of the TFY signal. Interpretation has proven difficult for these.
